course.description: The scope of this course is to introduce different categories of materials and to elucidate their applications. The focus of the course is the structure/property relationship. The principles for designing and developing useful materials for special applications will be discussed.

reviews.author: Alpha703
reviews.title: Quite good, but contents too technical for a common core course
reviews.comment_content:
(A brief summary of topics below)
Assessed in mid-term:
Atomic and crystal structures: Atomic structure and bonding, bcc/fcc/hcp structures, lattices, X-ray diffraction, solid solutions, types of defects
Diffusion: Process and rate of solid state diffusion
Mechanical Properties: Stress and strain, strength, ductility, toughness, hardness, Poisson’s ratio, Griffith crack model, deformations, creep
Thermal behavior: Heat capacity, thermal expansion, thermal conductivity, thermal shock
Assessed in final exam:
Phase diagrams: Phases, degree of freedom, microstructures, types of binary phase diagrams, Lever Rule
Heat treatment: Solidification, TTT diagrams, isothermal and martensitic transformation, heat treatment processes(e.g. tempering, age hardening)
Structure materials: Classification, uses, structure and properties of metals, ceramics, polymers and composites
Electronic Materials: Basic concept in electricity, valence and conduction bands, Fermi function, semi-conductors(n-type and p-type)

There are also two 'guest lectures': Prof. Sun and Prof. Luo from CENG department talked about biomaterials and nanomaterials respectively. They are less interesting and also won't be assessed in exams.

As a year 1 science student who registered this course as a common core, I think that some content of this course is too technical for a common core, emphasizing on some skills that we will barely use in daily life(except for chemical engineers). I also need some time to digest the new concepts in this course as a science student, but they are actually not very hard to understand. It is also strongly advised to have DSE-level Chemistry and Physics background before enrolling in this course. If you a looking for a s&t common core course maybe you should consider other courses first.

The contents are perfectly fine for a CENG required course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Shao is a responsible professor who can elaborate concepts clearly and are willing to answer student's questions. His English is sharp but plain, so it is somewhat easy to fall asleep in class, but when I watched the lecture videos I realized that he can explain things quite well. He will also demonstrate example questions in the lesson.

His lecture notes are simplified as much as possible, only containing the key points and some key examples to questions. Thus, you need to attend the lessons or watch the lecture videos in order to fully understand the contents, rather than just self-studying with notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
Homework: 10% Mid-term: 40% Final: 50%
OR
Homework: 10% Mid-term: 30% Final: 40% Project: 20%
5 marks will be deducted from total marks if you do not show up at least once in his office hour.

Prof. Shao claims that he will give 30-40% A range, 40% B range and  C or below for the rest. While I am not sure if it is true, I think the grading is still quite generous. I get exactly the mean in mid-term(75/100, SD: 12 If I remember it correctly), around 60-70% in homework(Estimated), 9x/100 in final(They didn't release final result, I just estimate by my performance that time, but the final should be easier than mid-term), went to office hour once, didn't do the project, finally I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.
Homework: One per week, each consists of 2-4 textbook questions, all are quite straightforward(provided that you understand the concepts), usually you only need to refer to the lecture notes to do them, but sometimes it is better to refer to the textbooks(can borrow from library). However, Prof. Shao said that he may make homeworks more difficult from next year.
Project: Optional. A ppt presentation on a specific type of materials (For example, materials in human bones) in the last 2 lessons. Not sure the details of it.
Office hour: The only 'attendance' of the course. You must show up at least once during his office hour, otherwise 5 marks will be deducted from your total score(he will keep record of who have shown up and who do not). If you don't have any questions to ask he will just ask you some opinions about the course and suggestions for improvements and then let you go.
Exams: I think you will need only a few hours to go through the lecture notes(provided that you attend all lessons/watch all lecture videos). You can borrow the non-compulsory textbook from library reserve to practice on the exam questions. For mid-term you should do more practice on calculations and for final you should do more practice on handling the diagrams(phase diagrams, TTT diagrams). You can ask the professor for detailed textbook solutions guide too.

The first half of the content has more calculations, so its easier to revise, since you only have to recognize which equations to use and understand those 3D stuff (lattice positions, planes).

The second half is a lot harder. Phase diagrams are very complicated and hard to analyze since there are many different variations and information embedded in it. Search on Youtube for more detailed and clearer explanations. I have studied lectures 11-13 for the longest time, at this moment I still am not sure what is going on in these chapters. The lectures after phase diagram are much more informative with fewer equations, such as introducing heat treatment methods, materials properties, etc.

Exams:
Midterm includes more calculations, whereas there's a large part in finals asks you to interpret the phase diagram and TTT diagram. Both exams do not have essay type questions.

Presentation:
You can choose to do or not. The topics are very wide, it only requires you to introduce a material, you don't have to link it with the concepts learnt. A group consists of 1-2 people, most people do it solo. The duration is 12-15 minutes. Some groups have references from DSE content. So its actually very easy to work on.
reviews.comment_teaching: His accent is quite strong, but still easy to understand. You really have to attend his lectures to understand what is going on, his notes are very brief and only include the main points, you can't understand a thing just by looking at the ppt. The professor is very nice too, he responds to my emails very quickly.

This course focuses on basic knowledge of material science. At the core, the topics try to give an understanding of the relationship between the atomic structure of a material and its macroscopic properties. Some lectures, like L7, get pretty technical but it is not that important to memorize all those details for the exam. Solving the exam and HW problems does not require complex math. Overall, the material is very interesting and good for Common Core.

L1 - Introduction
L2 - Atomic Structure and Bonding
L3 - Crystal Structure
L4 - Lattice Positions, Directions and Planes
L5 - X-Ray Diffraction
L6 - Crystal Defects

L8 - Mechanical Properties I
L9 - Mechanical Properties II
L10 - Thermal Behavior
L11/12 - Phase Diagrams I
L13 - Phase Diagrams II
L14 - Heat Treatment I

He also had an office hour every week to talk with him on zoom.

- Homework: 10%
- Midterm: 40%
- Final: 50%

Grading scheme (with presentation):
- Homework: 10%
- Midterm: 30%

- Final: 40%

The exams were open-book, open-notes. The midterm had more calculations and the final had more essay-type questions. The final was split in two parts. One of them was only about phase diagrams, so it is very important to understand how they work. Many of the question types were already discussed in lectures or tutorials, and they give enough time to do everything correctly.

1. 查表--> hkl (每個structure頭三個hkl)

• Scherrer eqn(β用'radian')[angle*180/pi],θ普通度數(Bragg angle)

• Hume-Rothery rules
1. atomic radii diff. <15%
2. same structure
3. EN diff. <30%
4. same Valence e(#最外層電子)
• Point defects
• linear/Planar defects

-2個temp,2個rate:Find Ea(呢個course叫 Q)

• poisson's ratio & shear stress

• MOR
• Griffith crack model(用crack解釋ceramics tensile &compress現象)
• Resolved shear stress
• ❗Hardness BHN formula(D,d in ❗mm❗)
• Creep stress,rate (Arrhenius eqn)

• Thermal Expansion
• Thermal conductivity
-> factor affect
• Thermal shock

1. Thermal expansion
2. Significant temp gradient.
